name: tris(3-methoxyphenyl)phosphine
Reason: 3-methoxyphenyl groups, when connected to a phosphine base, significantly increase the melting point due to the introduction of a rigid, planar structure with potential hydrogen bonding. Each methoxy group introduces additional molecular weight and van der Waals forces, raising the melting point by approximately +5 degrees Celsius. The phosphine base itself contributes to the melting point due to its rigidity and potential hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +10 degrees Celsius. The methoxy groups also increase the melting point due to their ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +5 degrees Celsius. The presence of three methoxy groups can contribute to the melting point due to their ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +15 degrees Celsius.
